17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the town and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Oatmeal, porridge, toast, tea, butter
milk, cream
Dinner: Potatoes, pork, veg., Bread, Butter
Biscuits - pudding
Supper: Potatoes, eggs, Bread, Butter, fruit
syrup, cake, coffee, doughnuts

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada? ...................... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

maybe 1899 - potatoes - chicken - headcheese
vegetables - pies - cakes - apples
myself, husband, a few bachelor from
neighbouring farms

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

no - we always had sufficient - even if at times
good plain food.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

meals were prepared by more work & less ready prepared ingredients etc.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

only in recent years - say the last 20 yrs.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

When you went to town or country store you bought a good supply - nowadays you go to the store 3 times a day. Food was just as good in old days. But more conveniently packaged or preserved now. Price now doesn't help - still going up.

In old days you could exchange butter, eggs, etc. Now all must go thru a cannery station or creamery.
